text: Say I have a stupidly simple question. Is this the right channel for that?

elements.text: Say I have a stupidly simple question. Is this the right channel for that?

text: Yes!! :) This channel welcomes all questions

elements.text: Yes!! :) This channel welcomes all questions

text: And thanks to the black hole, in a few months you can pretend you always knew everything!

elements.text: And thanks to the black hole, in a few months you can pretend you always knew everything!

text: <@UHEFY3GCV> Your SVD question on the Z_2 field was not stupidly simply haha :slightly_smiling_face:. Good  luck!! It sounds like a fun project. I think I wanted to do something vaguely similar before where I wanted to decompose a binary matrix into a lower rank while still keeping error as small as possible, but it was not the Z_2 field (it was where 1 + 1 = 1). I never figured it out though, I feel like it had something to do with discrete optimization instead

elements.text: Your SVD question on the Z_2 field was not stupidly simply haha

. Good  luck!! It sounds like a fun project. I think I wanted to do something vaguely similar before where I wanted to decompose a binary matrix into a lower rank while still keeping error as small as possible, but it was not the Z_2 field (it was where 1 + 1 = 1). I never figured it out though, I feel like it had something to do with discrete optimization instead

text: <@U0138UTB7A4> was that operation (`1 + 1 = 1`) the only operation, or was there another?

elements.text: ) the only operation, or was there another?

text: If I remember correctly, it was basically 1 + 1 = 1 and all the regular Z_2 field operations, just overriding 1+1

elements.text: If I remember correctly, it was basically 1 + 1 = 1 and all the regular Z_2 field operations, just overriding 1+1

text: It was boolean algebra, with `and` and `or`

I'm having a hard time finding it again, but I remember finding that the boolean algebra like in logic, did not follow the field axioms. They were not equivalent. So I couldn't simply use Z_2 field operations

elements.text: I'm having a hard time finding it again, but I remember finding that the boolean algebra like in logic, did not follow the field axioms. They were not equivalent. So I couldn't simply use Z_2 field operations

text: Oh well, it was for a side project that I never went to completion with. Maybe one day...

elements.text: Oh well, it was for a side project that I never went to completion with. Maybe one day...

text:
<@U0138UTB7A4> what you are describing is neither a field nor a ring, but a semiring. Matrices and modules (essentially, vector spaces) over semirings are not super well-known, but studied at pretty good depth. I found a source that might help if you ever want to revisit this project; cheers

<https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/002240499290108R>

attachments.title: The variety of Boolean semirings
attachments.text: The variety of Boolean semirings BIR is the variety generated by the two 2-element semirings. We find a complete set of laws for this variety, and shoâ€¦

elements.text: what you are describing is neither a field nor a ring, but a semiring. Matrices and modules (essentially, vector spaces) over semirings are not super well-known, but studied at pretty good depth. I found a source that might help if you ever want to revisit this project; cheers

text: Thank you!! Yes I can imagine this resource being really helpful. I was thinking of doing the decomposition using optimization, but yes maybe there's a way to calculate it using semiring matrix math magic
